Title: Albert Spalding - Barber Violin Concerto Premiere Feb 7, 1941 Live Broadcast E. Ormandy, Phil. Orch
Apostel Haydn Var Mussorgsky Pictures Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1964 Live
Description:
The Apostel was composed in 1949 to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Vienna Symphony Orchestra (the VSO, not the VPO). Here are excellent program notes from 2022 that I recommend:  https://ton.bard.edu/hans-erich-apostels-variations-on-a-theme-by-haydn/

I left in Pictures in the Ravel orchestration, despite the commercial availability of several recordings of this Philly Special under EO, Stokowski and Muti, but chiefly I refer to the 1966 one with these same forces, which is an undisputed reference in fantastic sound. Here as always, it sounds magnificent.

Title: Bach 3 Pf Cto Casadesus Carter Variations Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1962 Live
Description: The Bach Concerto for 3 Pianos had been recorded commercially by Columbia approximately 10 months before this performance and is remastered beautifully in the first Ormandy Columbia stereo box. Philadelphia has never commercially recorded any Elliott Carter, and this performance reveals the work as a perfect vehicle to show off both the players’ virtuosity, EO’s commitment to balance and proportion, and the players’ sharing in that commitment. Carter was present for this performance and for the open rehearsals that preceded it.  The work wasn’t shelved after this performance; 4 years later Skrowaczewski, during one of his many Philly guest conducting gigs, programmed the Carter Variations for a February 1966 Carnegie Hall performance.

Title: Bach Pass LvB Cto 3 Rubinstein Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1967 Live
Bach Suite 3 Badings Double Violin Cto 1 Brusilow Madison Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1962 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Bach's Orchestral Suite No. 3 (BWV 1068) with its familiar second movement (popularly referred to as the Air on the G String, commercially recorded 3x by Ormandy), and Henk Badings's 1954 Double Violin Concerto No. 1, with concertmaster Anshel Brusilow and associate concertmaster Davey Madison as soloists. Badings was prolific and has an interesting biography (putting aside the Nazi collaboration accusations, which must have been either disproven or unknown to Ormandy). The Badings concerto is thrilling, and I imagine Brusilow and Madison, who got along well according to Brusilow's Shoot the Conductor, had a great time playing it together.

Title: Barber's "Concerto for Violin & Orchestra" - LIVE!
Description:
Here is the official premiere performance of Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto with violinist Albert Spalding and the Philadelphia Orchestra under the direction of Eugene Ormandy.  From the Academy of Music in Philadelphia on February 7, 1941.

I.  Allegro
II.  Andante   10:19 
III.  Presto in moto perpetuo   18:23 

Barber provided these program notes for this premiere performance:
"The first movement—allegro molto moderato—begins with a lyrical first subject announced at once by the solo violin, without any orchestral introduction. This movement as a whole has perhaps more the character of a sonata than concerto form.
The second movement—andante sostenuto—is introduced by an extended oboe solo. The violin enters with a contrasting and rhapsodic theme, after which it repeats the oboe melody of the beginning.
The last movement, a perpetuum mobile, exploits the more brilliant and virtuosic character of the violin."

Title: Bartok 2 Portraits Carol Copland Organ Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1970 Live
Description: The Two Portraits (Op. 5) together with the Two Pictures (Op. 10) were commercially recorded by Philadelphia and Ormandy on Columbia, with then-concertmaster Anshel Brusilow on violin.  Here, in just the Two Portraits, we get to hear Norman Carol, who replaced Brusilow as concertmaster.  The Copland, both wistful and thrilling, played in honor of Copland's 70th birthday, was commissioned by Serge Koussevitzky so that Nadia Boulanger, Copland's teacher, could play the organ solo.  Copland was just 23 when he wrote it.  It was never commercially recorded by Philadelphia; instead, Columbia had Bernstein and the NY Philharmonic record it with E. Powers Biggs in 1967.

Title: Beethoven Cto 5 Cliburn Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1961 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 (the "Emperor") with soloist Van Cliburn, live in a subscription concert for the 1961-62 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  Ormandy and Philadelphia did not commercially record the Emperor in stereo.  There are two mono performances (1950 with Serkin and 1958 with Istomin), the latter of which was reportedly recorded in stereo but never issued that way.  (Columbia gave Serkin in stereo to Bernstein.) Van Cliburn was an RCA artist and so did not make any commercial recordings with Philadelphia until it jumped back to RCA in late 1968, but the only Beethoven they recorded together was a dreary, flatfooted performance of the Third concerto in 1971 that found both in poor form. (I found the subscription performance recording of that concerto, and it is equally limp and disappointing.) This performance, by contrast, displays the best of what Cliburn had to offer: power, precisely articulated fingerwork (those trills!), a full palette of touch, fluidity, and poise. He does make a few mistakes towards the end of mvt. i and in the middle of iii. Ormandy and Philadelphia supply taut and percussive yet cantabile accompaniment, with interesting phrasing and woodwinds gorgeously balanced forward at times. A few horn glitches in i are the only demerits in the accompaniment. This is a very good performance, and with some retakes would have been an excellent commercial release. Program notes are spoken by William Smith, the orchestra‘s longtime assistant conductor.

Title: Berg 3 Works Mozart Concertante Vn Va Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1964 Live
Description: Neither of these works was commercially recorded by Philadelphia under Ormandy, though they were no strangers to Berg (Wozzeck excerpts, Lulu Suite).  Read Mark Cogley's interesting comment below about the Berg.  It is nice to hear the Mozart with Anshel Brusilow and Joseph De Pasquale in such perfect ensemble.

Title: Brahms 3 Handel Var Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1961 Live
Description: Included because the shrill sonics of the commercial stereo recording by Columbia in 1967 make that performance pretty much unlistenable, and Robert Russ was apparently incapable of correcting the masters.  This is a perfect performance in great sound (favorably adjusted on the fly in the first few measures, I detect) with some audience noise. The third movement balances are exquisite, just magical, and the fourth movement is both a clinic about the benefits of disciplined maintenance of proportion and useful example of Ormandy’s ear at work. That's of course Gil Johnson in the Handel Variations.

Title: Brahms 4 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1961 Live
Description: Included because the shrill sonics of the commercial stereo recording by Columbia in 1967 make that performance pretty much unlistenable, and Robert Russ was apparently incapable of correcting the masters in the second Columbia stereo box. This is a nearly perfect performance in very good sound and with very little audience noise until the last movement when the coughing really gets going.

Title: Brahms Academic Double Cto Carol Mayes Philadelphia Ormandy March 1971 Live
Description: The treat here is hearing concertmaster Norman Carol and principal cello Sammy Mayes in a concert hall version of the Double Concerto, instead of two thirds of Stern-Rose-Istomin (commercially recorded closely miked in 1964 and now beautifully remastered) or Heifetz and Feuermann (from 1939 and issued remastered in 2025).  I left in the overture, which I've not once heard played at any academic festival I've ever attended, though it's given an exciting performance here.

Title: Brahms Cto 1 Rubinstein Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1967 Live
Description: Rubinstein, here just after his 80th birthday, plays a very good Brahms Piano Concerto No. 1, the real attraction of which is the gorgeous accompaniment, since Rubinstein was having a dexterity-challenged evening. The beginning of the third movement finds his 80-year-old fingers simply uncooperative. Since Rubinstein was an RCA artist, it was not until 1968 that he and Philadelphia started to record together in stereo, when his powers were in decline (more noticeable in the 1971 Rach 2 and Brahms 2 than in the 1968 Chopin 2, 1969 Saint-Saens 2 or 1971 Falla/Gardens). Still, this live performance is on the whole superior to his 1966 commercial stereo recording of the Brahms 1 with Boston under Leinsdorf, and the sound here, while suffering from tape reel rotation artifact that causes annoying left channel flutter for extended periods, is far better than RCA gave him in Boston or in his best commercial recording of this work, the 1954 with Reiner in Chicago.

Title: Brahms Cto 2 Cliburn Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1963 Live
Description: This was a concert that also included a Buxtehude Passacaglia and the Wm. Schuman 6, available separately on this channel.  The Brahms Bb is in far better sound here than in the commercially released 1960 Ormandy/EO studio performance with Serkin that preceded it or the 1965 Ormandy/PO studio performance with Istomin that followed it (both on Columbia).  Cliburn makes some mistakes from the very beginning, but in general is in better and shapelier form than in his rubato-draggy 1972 live performance with Kondrashin and the Moscow Philharmonic at the Moscow Conservatory (released by RCA).  Lorne Munroe performs the cello solo in mvt. iii here (as opposed to Elsa Hilger in 1960, whose playing Serkin adored so EO wisely went with that, or Sammy Mayes in 1965 after Munroe had left for New York having been poached by Bernstein).  Since the Brahms Cto 2 was a favorite of EO's (5 commercial recordings, 2 in mono and 3 in stereo) the orchestra knows the accompaniment backward and forward and it's just perfect.  With some retakes (for Cliburn, not the orchestra), this would have been a reference recording for sure, but alas Cliburn was an RCA artist, not Columbia.

Title: Brahms Vn Cto Brusilow Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1963 Live
Description: Brusilow and Ormandy are completely in agreement here about how this concerto should sound, and it is gratifying to hear our very own concertmaster with his sweet tone and perfect intonation as soloist instead of some ringer.  (That same pride is why Philadelphia audiences went absolutely wild when our associate concertmaster Juliette Kang turned in a fantastic Bartok 2 this year with inspired hand in glove accompaniment by Yannick and her peers.)

Title: Britten Misericordium Strauss Death Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1965 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the American premiere of Britten’s Cantata Misericordium, composed in 1963 to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the founding of the International Red Cross. Singing City Chorale, a well-known avocational choir in Philadelphia since 1948 (and counting!), provides the vocal forces under the direction of its founder, Dr. Elaine Brown. Ormandy/Philadelphia nearly always employed non-professional choirs for live and commercially-recorded performances. With Elaine Brown and Robert Page at the helm of those choirs, vocal quality is assured to be top notch. Boatwright (baritone) and to a lesser extent Di Virgilio (tenor) are familiar names and voices to Philadelphia in these decades and can be found in works elsewhere on this channel. I left in Death and Transfiguration by Strauss, which Philadelphia has recorded commercially lots of times, under Stokowski, Toscanini, and Ormandy (3x!). (I personally think it’s Strauss’s least convincing work --- screechy, cheesy, and forced.)

Title: Britten Sym Requiem Yardumian 2 Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1964 Live
Description: The Britten, whose first movement seems influenced by the first movement of Mahler’s 9th, is exciting as hell and shows off Philadelphia’s unmatched and versatile virtuosity. They don’t seem to break a sweat and remain tightly disciplined and in perfect proportion, particularly when the notes are coming fast and furious. Let’s also give credit to Mr. Borkow and Mr. Sacks for the marvelous sound picture they created. Yardumian, championed by Ormandy at least in part due to Pitcairn money, is heard here in a world premiere with Lili Chookasian, a contralto Ormandy favored in commercial recordings. The juxtaposition of these two works underscores that Britten was the superior (and certainly more imaginative) composer and that Philadelphia is able to play to a fare-thee-well just about anything put before it.

Title: Bruckner 7 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1968
Description: Bruckner Symphony No. 7, Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy.  Recorded for RCA in October of 1968.  Among the first recordings after the jump back to RCA from Columbia.  A brisk performance that shows off Philadelphia's virtuosity.  Ormandy previously recorded this work with the Minnesota (then called the Minneapolis), back in 1935. This excellent performance is not widely available.

Title: Buxtehude Chaccone LvB Cto 5 Istomin Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1964 Live
Description: The Buxtehude E minor chaconne was arranged by Mexican composer and conductor Carlos Chavez.  This performance of the Beethoven Emperor concerto sounds very much like the 1958 commercial recording, which had reportedly been recorded by Columbia in stereo but never issued that way, and apparently Robert Russ and company either couldn't find the stereo master or it was lost decades ago. If you wanted to hear Istomin in stereo instead of just in mono, here's your chance.  There are some small mistakes both by Istomin and in the Philly horns, but the performance itself is percussive and energetic, putting the lie to the prevailing myth that Ormandy played Beethoven grazioso to a fault.

Title: Carter Holiday Ov Schumann Pf Cto Fischer Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1967 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Elliott Carter's Holiday Overture and Schumann's Piano Concerto with soloist Annie Fischer, aged 53 at the time of this concert.  The Carter work was composed in 1944, commissioned by the BSO to celebrate the liberation of Paris during WW2.  The Schumann is riddled with mistakes by Maestro Fischer, which apparently was something to be expected of her and tolerated.  Jonathan Summers, an academic and Curator of Classical Music at the British Library wrote in his book A-Z of Pianists, "[l]ike Cortot though, Fischer often played wrong notes in her performances, and, again as with Cortot, these did not detract from the strength of her interpretations, and certainly did not matter."  With the embarrassment of riches we have in pianists who are able to produce characterful, searching interpretations with no loss in accuracy, I find this apologia difficult to understand, but Summers' view is shared by many.

Title: Chausson Sym Bb Satie Gymnopedies 1 2 3 Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1964 Live
Description: The second Gymnopedie is arranged by Bill Smith, the first and third are the familiar Debussy arrangements. But the real treasure here in my opinion is the Chausson.  Ormandy and Philly only commercially recorded the Poeme (in mono in 1950 with Francescatti), never the symphony.  Those more familiar with the commercial releases by Munch, Paray and Monteux should let us know how Philly compares.

Title: Corelli Grosso Delius Cuckoo Volkmann Cello Hilger Philadelphia Ormandy March 1962 Live
Description: The real treat here is hearing Elsa Hilger, hired in 1935 by Stokowski and later promoted to second chair by Ormandy, in the Volkmann Cello Concerto.  It's a great piece (Volkmann was a cellist).  She retired in 1969 from the orchestra as union rules required.  Excerpts of her interview following Ormandy's death appear in the "posts" section of this channel.  She can also be heard live in the Haydn Cello Concerto No. 2 (uploaded elsewhere in this channel) and in the third movement of the 1960 stereo commercial recording of the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 with Serkin, who so loved her playing that he successfully urged Ormandy to let her have that solo (instead of Lorne Munroe). Subscription concert listings show she also soloed in the Tchaikovsky Rococo variations under Ormandy's baton in December of 1950, a work she had performed with the Vienna Philharmonic when she was just 12 years of age.  The Corelli is beautiful (and was never commercially recorded, unlike the G minor concerto grosso, which appears in the first Ormandy stereo box), and the Delius is legendary (and appears remastered in the first Ormandy stereo box).

Title: Delius Cuckoo Garden Barber Vn Cto Carol Philadelphia Ormandy Aug 1967 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in two Delius works (On Hearing the First Cuckoo in Spring and In a Summer Garden) and in Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto with concertmaster Norman Carol soloing.  I left in the Delius, although it was commercially recorded for Columbia in 1960 and 1962 (along with Brigg Fair and, in 1961, Dance Rhapsody No. 2) and has been remastered in wonderful sound in the first Columbia Stereo Box; before that, it was available in very good sound from Sony Japan (SICC2134) paired with Elgar, Walton, and Vaughan Williams works (a real banger of a CD).  The gem here is the Barber with Carol, which is very, very special, both because it was the piece that Carol played as his solo premiere in Philadelphia in 1966 after being appointed concertmaster, and because Philadelphia under Ormandy gave the work its world premiere (with Albert Spalding, on the very same violin that ultimately was purchased by Carol) in 1941. (The partial chain of title for that Guarnerius was Spalding, Felix Slatkin, then Carol.)  Carol reported that he had a special feeling for this concerto, and it shows. Philadelphia has never commercially recorded the Barber Violin Concerto.

Title: Dvorak 7 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1976
Description: Dvorak Symphony No. 7 by the Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy.  This performance was recorded for RCA in October of 1976.  This excellent performance is not widely available.

Title: Eppert Cto Grosso Haydn Vc Cto 2 Munroe Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1961 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Carl Eppert's Concerto Grosso in C minor, for flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, and string orchestra, and Haydn's Cello Concerto No. 2 with first chair Lorne Munroe as soloist.  Bill Smith's expression of hope that Eppert heard the performance over the radio indicates that this work, composed in 1940, was played as a "get well" message to the ill composer, who would die just 8 months later following a long illness that began in 1947.  Ormandy and Eppert were obviously well acquainted; EO and John Barbirolli (then leading the NYPO) were on the jury for the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's golden jubilee composition contest in 1941, for which Eppert won with his Symphonic Suite (aka Two Symphonic Impressions), a work originally intended as a ballet depicting a battle between preventive medicine and disease.  Ormandy and Philadelphia had also premiered Eppert's final symphony, titled The Image of America, in 1947.  This Concerto Grosso is a nice enough work, in whose first movement I hear echoes of the first movement of Ives' Symphony No. 1.  The Haydn is a pleasant vehicle to hear Lorne Munroe's artistry.

Title: Eugene Ormandy & Wiener Philharmoniker - Beethoven & Mozart (Sonderkonzert, 1963)
Description:
Ludwig van Beethoven (1770-1827): Symphony No. 8 in F Major, Op. 93
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791): Piano Concerto No. 21 in C major, KV 467

Rudolf Serkin, piano
Wiener Philharmoniker
Eugene Ormandy, cond.

#beethoven #mozart #classicalmusic 

Eugene Ormandy, direttore d'orchestra ungherese naturalizzato statunitense, è una figura di spicco nella storia della musica classica. Noto per la sua lunga e fruttuosa collaborazione con la Philadelphia Orchestra, Ormandy ha lasciato un'impronta indelebile nel mondo della musica sinfonica.

La Wiener Philharmoniker, fondata nel 1842, è una delle orchestre più prestigiose al mondo. Con sede a Vienna, ha una lunga tradizione di esecuzioni di altissimo livello e ha collaborato con i più grandi direttori d'orchestra di tutti i tempi.

L'incontro tra Ormandy e la Wiener Philharmoniker è stato un evento particolarmente significativo. Sebbene la maggior parte della carriera di Ormandy sia legata alla Philadelphia Orchestra, il direttore ungherese ha avuto l'opportunità di dirigere anche la Wiener Philharmoniker in diverse occasioni.

Queste collaborazioni hanno dato vita a registrazioni e concerti memorabili, che hanno dimostrato l'affinità artistica tra Ormandy e l'orchestra viennese. La sonorità ricca e opulenta della Wiener Philharmoniker si è sposata perfettamente con lo stile di direzione di Ormandy, creando un sound inconfondibile.

Due capolavori a confronto: Beethoven e Mozart

La Sinfonia n. 8 in Fa maggiore, Op. 93 di Beethoven e il Concerto per pianoforte n. 21 in Do maggiore, KV 467 di Mozart rappresentano due vertici del repertorio classico, seppur appartenenti a stili e periodi diversi.

La Sinfonia di Beethoven è un'opera di grande ingegno e vitalità, caratterizzata da una scrittura orchestrale brillante e da una struttura formale rigorosa. Nonostante la sua apparente leggerezza, l'opera cela una profondità espressiva sorprendente, rivelando l'evoluzione stilistica del compositore verso un linguaggio più intimo e personale.

Il Concerto per pianoforte di Mozart è un gioiello di grazia e virtuosismo. Il dialogo tra il pianoforte solista e l'orchestra è affascinante, e le melodie sono memorabili. Mozart, con la sua maestria compositiva, crea un equilibrio perfetto tra virtuosismo e lirismo.

A cosa prestare attenzione ascoltando queste opere:

Beethoven: La ricchezza timbrica dell'orchestra, lo sviluppo tematico e le sorprese armoniche.
Mozart: L'eleganza delle melodie, l'equilibrio tra virtuosismo e lirismo, e la brillantezza dell'orchestrazione.
Entrambe le opere offrono un'esperienza musicale intensa e coinvolgente, rivelando il genio creativo di due dei più grandi compositori di tutti i tempi.

***

Eugene Ormandy, a Hungarian-born American conductor, is a prominent figure in the history of classical music. Renowned for his long and fruitful collaboration with the Philadelphia Orchestra, Ormandy left an indelible mark on the world of symphonic music.

The Vienna Philharmonic, founded in 1842, is one of the most prestigious orchestras in the world. Based in Vienna, it has a long tradition of performing at the highest level and has collaborated with the greatest conductors of all time.

The encounter between Ormandy and the Vienna Philharmonic was a particularly significant event. Although most of Ormandy's career is linked to the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Hungarian conductor had the opportunity to conduct the Vienna Philharmonic on several occasions.

These collaborations have produced memorable recordings and concerts, demonstrating the artistic affinity between Ormandy and the Viennese orchestra. The rich and opulent sound of the Vienna Philharmonic has blended perfectly with Ormandy's conducting style, creating an unmistakable sound.

Two Masterpieces Compared: Beethoven and Mozart

Beethoven's Symphony No. 8 in F major, Op. 93, and Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21 in C major, K. 467, represent two pinnacles of the classical repertoire, although they belong to different styles and periods.

Beethoven's Symphony is a work of great ingenuity and vitality, characterized by brilliant orchestral writing and a rigorous formal structure. Despite its apparent lightness, the work conceals a surprising expressive depth, revealing the composer's stylistic evolution towards a more intimate and personal language.

Mozart's Piano Concerto is a jewel of grace and virtuosity. The dialogue between the solo piano and the orchestra is fascinating, and the melodies are memorable. Mozart, with his compositional mastery, creates a perfect balance between virtuosity and lyricism.

What to listen for when listening to these works:

Beethoven: The rich timbre of the orchestra, the thematic development, and the harmonic surprises.
Mozart: The elegance of the melodies, the balance between virtuosity and lyricism, and the brilliance of the orchestration.

BIO: "Eugene Ormandy was a Hungarian-born American conductor who was identified with the Late Romantic and early 20th-century repertoire.

Ormandy graduated from the Budapest Royal Academy, where he studied violin with Jenö Hubay, at age 14. By age 17 he was a professor of violin, undertaking concert tours throughout Central Europe. Lured to New York City by the prospect of a U.S. tour, he instead ended up playing the violin in the orchestra of the Capitol Theatre, accompanying silent films. In 1924 he stood in for the regular conductor and thereupon chose conducting as his career. He began conducting light classics for radio and appearing at summer concerts, which led to a position as deputy for Arturo Toscanini during a major concert series of the Philadelphia Orchestra. A contract with the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra ensued, and he remained there from 1931 to 1936, gaining national prominence with a series of recordings. He returned to the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1936 to share the conductorship with Leopold Stokowski. In 1938 Ormandy was made principal conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, a post that he held until he retired in 1980. Ormandy shaped the orchestra’s sound by developing the lush, velvety string colour that became its trademark."

Remastered By: Wayne Yang, USA-Taiwan

Title: Finney 3 Schumann Pf Cto Serkin Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1964 Live
Description: The Finney is a world premiere of an Ormandy commission.  Finney taught for many years at the University of Michigan, and Philadelphia played for many years at the May Festival in Ann Arbor, including Finney's Symphony No. 2 under Ormandy's baton (in 1960).  I left the Schumann in, although there are 3 commercial releases of it with Serkin and Philadelphia, all on Columbia, two in mono (1946 and 1956) and one in stereo (1964) for which this performance is surely the rehearsal before repairing to a recording session at Philadelphia's so-called Town Hall a/k/a Scottish Rite Cathedral at 150 N. Broad Street (demolished in 1983, despite John De Lancie's successful efforts a decade earlier to delay its demolition, which he said would represent “one more blow to the organizations that try, against overwhelming financial odds, to achieve stability and provide cultural activities that a city of this size deserves.”  De Lancie was at that time the director of the Curtis Institute of Music, and Richard Woodhams had succeeded him as our principal oboe.).

Title: Foss Improvising Cto Respighi Feste Romane Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1960 Live
Description:
I left the Respighi in as a chaser, a renowned Philly virtuosity showpiece, particularly in the frenzied last movement. Another excellent example of Ormandy’s ear and the players’ impressive discipline at work, resulting in balances in the fff tutti passages that ensure no instrumental choir is obscured by the others, and with no loss in excitement. 

The Foss work is undeniably well played and the sound is fantastic, putting aside its merit. This was not Ormandy and Philadelphia’s first rodeo with Lukas Foss, or their last. 

Here’s what Time Magazine had to say about the Foss work in October of 1960. The article is entitled “Classical Hipsters,” and reveals that after this world premiere the work was taken to Carnegie Hall:

Composers used to like nothing better than to sit down at the harpsichord or pianoforte and improvise on their own works. Bach, Handel and Beethoven were as well known for their improvisations as for their written compositions. Now Composer-Pianist Lukas Foss, 38, is contriving, with the help of a $10,000 Rockefeller grant, to put the long dead custom back into classical music—and make it an ensemble art.

The idea of “controlled improvisation” to free classical music from its “slavery to the printed note” first occurred to Composer Foss while listening to the high-brow jazz of the Modern Jazz Quartet three years ago. Foss invited a group of classical players—all former composition students of his at U.C.L.A.—to get together and improvise freely in a classical counterpart to the jazz manner. They soon had to give up that approach: “We just daydreamed; we didn’t make music.” What he was looking for, Foss realized, was a group improvisation in which every player would in some way be responsible to the others.

Pivotal Notes. Foss began to construct a system built around a series of pre-agreed pivotal notes and a system of letters that indicated what roles the various instruments were to assume at different times. Now he has abandoned the idea of pivotal notes, but the group still starts with “a certain musical vision,” worked out in countless rehearsals and set down in graphs and Foss’s own specially devised symbols. “If we hit something good,” says Foss, “we try to remember it. If something bad, we try to forget it.” The technique, insist the players, is far more complex than that of jazz. “It’s the difference between playing slapjack and playing bridge.”

Foss and his group of composer-performers, known as the Improvisation Chamber Ensemble, appeared at Carnegie Hall last week with the visiting Philadelphia Orchestra to display their technique in somewhat elaborated form. Their scheduled piece, certainly the oddest they have yet attempted, was titled Concerto for Improvising Solo Instruments and Orchestra. Pianist Foss and his men—flute, cello, clarinet and percussion—were ranged downstage in front of the orchestra, and Conductor Eugene Ormandy only rarely cast a nervous backward glance at them.

Controlled Chance. The Concerto consisted of three movements, actually written down for the orchestra by different members of the ensemble and “edited” by Foss. The music was rather faceless—tricked out with a full Modern Composer’s Kit of dissonances, rhythmic angularities, splashy climaxes. Against this background, Foss and the ensemble worked out their improvisations. It was in the Intermezzo, when the orchestra was silent, that Foss’s technique of “controlled chance” came into fullest play. The Foss ensemble was free to improvise—and it did, with some highly interesting results. The instruments traded themes, stitched their own sinewy figurations, advanced and retreated from the solo role.

For the most part the effect was spare and angular—a little like the small-toned, pointillistic compositions of Anton von Webern.

Innovator Foss, who is back teaching at U.C.L.A. after a year’s sabbatical for composition, does not expect his system to replace the written score. He himself has just completed a fully written-out composition, Time Cycle, for Soprano and Orchestra (to texts by Auden, Housman, Kafka and Nietzsche), which will be played for the first time by the New York Philharmonic this week. Between numbers, Foss’s ensemble will do improvised “commentaries” on the songs. With the spread of controlled improvisation, Foss thinks the day may come when a typical concert will begin with bits of Bartok or Beethoven and, in between, feature the members of a chamber group spinning out their own trackless flights of fancy.

Title: Gershwin Am in Paris Cto in F Bolet Philadelphia Ormandy Aug 1967 Live
Gesensway Commem'n Sym  Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1971 Live
Description:
Of his “Commemoration Symphony,” composed between 1964 and 1966 to commemorate his 40th and Ormandy’s 30th anniversary with the orchestra, and here given its somewhat delayed world premiere in an abridged form, Louis Gesensway (who was a violinist in our orchestra from 1926 through his retirement in 1971) wrote:

“The underlying theme is life and death. We come into this world with a cataclysmic force. We are thereby set into motion until we leave abruptly and sometimes violently. The mode of our existence depends entirely on the way we develop through all of our experiences. These are the resuits of a continuous struggle with the forces of nature, the emotions within ourselves, and the conflicts within society. The struggle, however, is not always intense. The mood changes within each movement suggest man’s frequent frustrations and his occasional realization of attainment. The close of the symphony, representing death, comes with a crescendo in the percussion and with a timpani roll which dies away to the end.

“First Movement (Allegro, Molto Agitato) opens with a crash in the percussion and short, rhythmic pulses. It is in the basic sonata form.

“Second Movement (Vivace, Molto Ritmico) is written in a lighter mood, with rapid and unusual rhythmic dance motifs. A feeling of jazz prevails.

“Third Movement (Sostenuto, Andante Lugubrioso) is slow, expressing feelings of tenderness and sadness. Prominent oboe solos occur in the opening and closing sections. The movement ends very quietly with a timpani solo.

“Final Movement (Allegro Giusto) is constructed on three principal themes, playful in spirit, which are developed and then recapitulated with varied orchestrations. The third theme is broken off suddenly; a drum roll and crash slowly die away to the end.”

I encourage you to listen to the interview of Gesensway, which is uploaded separately here at the beginning of the second half of the concert, comprising the Mendelssohn violin concerto played by Norman Carol and (yet another) La Mer. His perspective as both an orchestral player and a composer is fascinating.  He was a prolific composer, and developed a system he called “color harmony“ by expanding and contracting the intervals of the diatonic scale into fractions.

The Philadelphia Orchestra and Ormandy were loyal to their own, and this is just one example. They commercially recorded for Columbia Gesensway’s Four Squares of Philadelphia in a 1955 performance, available remastered in the Ormandy mono box.

Title: Gliere Horn Cto Jones Flanagan Ode Ravel Valse Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1961 Live
Description: This concert was in observance of the 15th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. The Flanagan Concert Ode, with Flanagan on hand to hear it, is beautiful and bears out his mentoring by Copland. The Gliere is good, but Mason Jones (who gave the work its American premiere in Teaneck, New Jersey) is surpassed here by any number of other soloists in this work. The ends of his phrases compete with his anticipation of taking a breath, he fluffs lots of notes, and he seems more pokerfaced than characterful. La Valse is quite good but bettered by both Columbia commercial recordings (1953’s barnburner in mono — a real jaw-dropper, that one — and 1963 in stereo).

Title: Handel Org Cto 4 Ellsasser Stravinsky Nightingale Dello Joio Antiphonal Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 19
Handel Pastoral Rach Cto 3 Gilels Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1966 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in the “Pastoral Symphony” interlude from Handel’s Messiah and in a rare and important find Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No. 3 with soloist Emil Gilels. Gilels, in the midst of his 6th North American tour, gives an exciting performance using the lighter cadenza (as was his wont), a performance that he would reprise 11 days later in Carnegie Hall. That latter performance has been available on Melodiya for years, but as one commenter points out the sound achieved here by Messrs. Borkow and Sacks is far superior, making this recording a welcome discovery. There is some slight warble in the transfer from tape to digital that is the only demerit to the sonics; microphones and piano/orchestra balance are ideal. There are a few mistakes, these start piling up in the breathless finale. The audience goes crazy at the conclusion, stomping their feet demanding an encore (which, if given, was not captured), enthusiasm not typically demonstrated by Academy of Music audiences. The Handel is gorgeously played, too.

Title: Hanson 2 Telemann Flute Panitz Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1963 Live
Description: The Hanson, titled the "Romantic" and commissioned by Koussevitzky in 1930, is spectacularly played.  Philadelphia has commercially recorded no Hanson symphonies, but did give the world premiere of Hanson's Fifth at Carnegie Hall in 1955 under Ormandy's baton. And Murray Panitz in the Telemann is wonderful and gets quite a workout.  Panitz succeeded William Kincaid, and following Panitz's untimely death in 1989 we gained our current principal flute, Jeffrey Khaner.  Three giants in an essentially unbroken chain spanning more than a century (1921-present).

Title: Haydn 100 Piston 7 Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1961 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Haydn's Symphony No. 100 (the "Military") and the world premiere of Walter Piston's Symphony No. 7, commissioned by the Philadelphia Orchestra and composed from 1960-61.  Piston is present at this premiere.  The Piston would go on to win the 1961 Pulitzer Prize for Music. Assistant conductor William Smith explains that when Piston was composing his Seventh Symphony, he took into account the particular sonic character of the Philadelphia Orchestra's rich string timbres, as well as the acoustics of the Academy of Music.  Philadelphia under Ormandy commercially recorded the Haydn in 1953 for Columbia, available remastered in the Ormandy mono box.

Title: Kabalevsky Colas Saens Rondo Kim Dukas Sorcerer Liszt Cto 1 Watts Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1964
Description: This special gala concert celebrated the 107th anniversary of the Academy of Music, which Bill Smith reminds us was called “the Grand Old Lady of Locust Street.” Solo violinist Young-Uck Kim was just 16 and solo pianist Andre Watts just 18 at the time of this concert. Kim entered Curtis in 1961, was taught by Ivan Galamian (who also taught Veda Reynolds, hired by Ormandy in 1943, the first woman in our violin section) and had his national debut in a televised concert with Philadelphia under Ormandy the previous year, 1963, just one of many examples of solo careers launched from our orchestra during the Ormandy years.  Andre Watts was another example:  he played the Mendelssohn 1 at the Dell at age 9, and debuted in a subscription concert at age 14 in the Franck Symphonic Variations.  Exactly one year before this concert, Watts played the Liszt 1 on national TV with the NY Philharmonic under Bernstein. Both Kim and Watts went on to have successful solo careers, both on stage and in the recording studio.  Kim gives a masterful performance of the Saint-Saens (repeatedly recorded commercially with Francescatti, Stern, and Dylana Jenson), and Watts generates lots of drama and excitement in the Liszt (repeatedly recorded commercially with Arrau, Entremont [my personal favorite], and Cliburn) and at a couple of points tries to outrun Ormandy, which is lots of fun.  The infrequently-heard Kabelevsky is a rousing opening, and I left the warhorse Dukas in, played to a fare-thee-well despite a single horn glitch.

Title: Kanitz Bassoon Cto Garfield Prokofiev 7 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1967 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Ernest Kanitz's Bassoon Concerto, featuring principal bassoon Bernard Garfield and Prokofiev's Symphony No. 7.  The bassoon concerto was composed in 1964, and Maestro Garfield shows it off to its best advantage, aided by the orchestra and EO's careful dynamics. I think Bernard Garfield was far more than a principal bassoonist; he was a musical philosopher, as the extracts of his interview with Sharon Eisenhour, posted in this channel, reveal.  The Prokofiev, which received its American premiere in Philadelphia in April of 1953 under Ormandy's baton, was promptly recorded commercially for Columbia in mono in April of 1953.  Philadelphia never returned to the recording studio, with Ormandy or anyone else, to capture the Prokofiev 7 in stereo, though it was programmed with some frequency in these decades, so it is nice to have this spirited stereo performance.

Title: LvB Calm Sea Choral Fantasy Serkin Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1970 Live
Description: The cantata is so brief perhaps the word cantatette should be coined.  Definitely good for those with short attention spans.  The Choral Fantasy is just excellent in every single way.  One commenter used the word "exuberant," and he is right on, in my opinion.  Columbia had given the Choral Fantasy with Serkin to Bernstein and the NYPO for a commercial recording, and while I love that version, this one is even better played and sung, certainly more interestingly so.  Serkin sounds great at 66 years of age here.  EO would use amateur choral forces instead of professional, as illustrated in this concert.  Here, it's the Mendelssohn Club of Philadelphia (now called the Mendelssohn Chorus), which Philly still calls upon for live performances.  Temple University, Rutgers University, and of course for commercial recordings the Mormon Tabernacle were used through the decades, as have local community choirs (Newark Boys' and Philly Boys, to name just two).  I personally love this practice of eschewing professional choirs in favor of local and amateur forces, but others have registered disapproval, particularly when discussing the pronunciation of non-English words (and for the Mormons, even English ones!).

Title: Mahler 1 Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1963 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Mahler Symphony No. 1 live in the opening subscription concert for the 1963-64 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  This performance is better recorded than the 1969 commercial performance issued by RCA (which unlike this performance featured the "Blumine" movement).  I had read that Ormandy was very good in the Mahler 1, but you wouldn't know it from that RCA disc. By contrast, this performance demonstrates it clearly.  Ormandy finds all kinds of interesting orchestration to highlight and balance, and apparently did some rescoring, including bells in the finale.  The players are committed, with characterful phrasing and tasteful portamenti in the strings throughout. (The theme of the program was Vienna, so perhaps everybody was Vienna-ing things up.) There's a horn glitch in ii, fatigue becomes evident in the horns and brass in iv, and I think one of the celli may have gone flat in iv. Nevertheless, a superlative performance that suggests to me that rather than debating whether Bernstein/NYPO or Walter/CSO should have been released first in this work (Bernstein reportedly "gave way" to Walter after hearing John McClure's master tape), Columbia would have done better to look to Ormandy/PO.  I also now think, on the basis of this performance, that Ormandy had more to say in the Mahler 1 than Muti did in the PO's justly highly regarded 1984 commercial recording on EMI.  Program notes are spoken by William Smith, the orchestra‘s longtime assistant conductor.

Title: Mahler 10 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1967 Live
Mahler 3 Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1972 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Mahler Symphony No. 3 live in the opening subscription concert for the 1972-73 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts, with mezzo soprano Betty Allen, the women of the Mendelssohn Club, and the Newark Boys' Chorus.  Ormandy calls out for special applause principal trombone Glenn Dodson, principal trumpet Gil Johnson, and concertmaster Norman Carol.  It's a good performance, not great, marred by some broken first movement trumpet notes by Johnson, horn notes by Mason Jones, and even a missed piccolo lick by John Krell. Dodson's relative lack of vulgarity and the Academy of Music's dead acoustic result in first movement trombone solos that may be too polite and not sufficiently primordial for some. As a final demerit, Betty Allen pushes herself too hard in iv, leading to a strained, throaty “Kermit the frog” sound at times.

Title: Mahler 4 Philadelphia Ormandy March 1972 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Mahler Symphony No. 4 live in a subscription concert for the 1971-72 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts, with soprano Evelyn Mandac. This performance is sublime, with phrasing, ensemble and balances that are quintessential Philadelphia under Ormandy. Make sure you compare this with the 1960 performance, also available on this channel.

Title: Mahler 4 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1960 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Mahler Symphony No. 4  live in a subscription concert for the 1960-61 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts, with soprano Camilla Williams (regrettably misidentified as "Pamela" in the thumbnail).  Another sublime live performance of the Fourth, which supplies a very interesting comparison against the March 1972 performance available on this channel.  Out of the gate, Ormandy sets a brisk pace, though the total timings of the two performances are not much different, perhaps because there is greater flexibility of tempo throughout this performance.  Perhaps it's the microphone placement, but in the 1972 performance Ormandy seems to devote greater attention to balances, especially noticeable in ii.  Associate conductor Bill Smith's oral program notes, delivered in his trademark deadpan, are interesting as usual.  Camilla Williams' vocal timbre to my ear is just perfect for iv.  Had Columbia decided to commercially record Philly/Ormandy/Williams in this work, I think it would have rivaled Reiner's contemporaneous (and to my ear somewhat cold) RCA release with Lisa Della Casa. But Bernstein was busy recording the Mahler symphonies at this time for Columbia. A listener reports that the recording or its archival transfer is sped up, causing the entire performance and Bill Smith’s voice to be a half step sharp.

Title: MAURIZIO POLLINI  Live 1971  BRAHMS Piano Concerto #2   Phildelphia Orchestra c Ormandy
Description: BRAHMS: Piano Concerto #2 in Bb, Op 83. Maurizio Pollini live debut performance with the Philadelphia Orchestra c Eugene Ormandy, from WQXR broadcast of 28 November 1971.

Title: Mendelssohn 4 Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1963 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Mendelssohn Symphony No. 4 ("Italian") live in a subscription concert for the 1963-64 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  I included this because I find the string sound in the October 1963 commercial stereo recording (for Columbia) to be too heavy, deliberate, and lacking in the dash and elan that I am used to in Mendelssohn. I much prefer this live performance, which is bouncier and faster, with deliciously lighter string tone. Murray Panitz and the flute battery are magnificent in iv. A horn glitch in mvt. i is the only demerit. (The numerous cracked horn notes I have heard thus far in these live performances make me wonder if I should appreciate Montone, Lang, Dwyer, Torres and McFarland a bit more.) Program notes are spoken by William Smith, the orchestra‘s longtime assistant conductor. ￼

Title: Mendelssohn Vn Cto Carol Debussy Mer Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1971 Live
Description: Norman Carol deserves far more acclaim than he receives, and it is nice to hear him play the Mendelssohn so well instead of having to rely on commercial recordings by Spalding, Stern (x2), or Oistrakh (just the second Stern in stereo).  He has a varied range of tone here, from beefy to sweet (but never brittle), his phrasing is always refined, and he is undefeatable in the breakneck final movement, which is thrilling.  I left La Mer in (which can be compared to the January 1964 live version, separately uploaded and paired with Francescatti playing the Saint-Saens Violin Concerto No. 3). This upload begins with Louis Gesensway describing his Commemoration Symphony, also separately uploaded, and both the symphony and Gesensway should be heard.  His perspective as a fiddler turned composer is unique and fascinating.  Guess where he prefers to sit to audition his works?

Title: Mennin Canto Strauss Gentilhomme Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1965 Live
Messiaen L’ Ascension - Ormandy / Philadelphia orc. (1974)
Description: Eugene Ormandy - Philadelphia Orchestra (01.1974)

Title: Mozart 30 LvB Cto 3 Firkusny Philadelphia Ormandy March 1962 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Mozart's Symphony No. 30 and Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3 with Czech soloist Rudolf Firkusny, an American citizen and New Yorker since 1953.  The Mozart would the following month be taken into Philadelphia's Town Hall (150 N. Broad St., demolished in 1983) for a commercial recording by Columbia on April 8, 1962.  The Beethoven finds Firkusny confidently speeding along in the first movement, outrunning EO and the orchestra on occasion, causing some minor occasional ensemble issues in the accompaniment.  This is an athletic and energetic performance, breathless at times, with close-up sound that is like an X-ray exposing Firkusny's commanding virtuosity.  The first movement cadenza is thrilling, so the audience can't help applauding between movements.  We have a cougher who mars the quiet second movement largo.  Firkusny's third movement fingerwork is astonishing in its fusion of beauty, precision, and speed.  He tries to outrun the orchestra at times, but they're twice shy and not having it.  A memorable performance; I cannot name a better one of this work.

Title: Mozart 35 Brahms Vn Cto Goldberg Philadelphia Ormandy Aug 1967 Live
Mozart 35 Webern Sommerwind Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1963 Live
Description:
The jewel here is the Haffner, since the late Mozart symphonies weren’t commercially recorded in stereo by Philadelphia, Columbia (justly) giving them to Bruno Walter and the so-called Columbia Symphony Orchestra (LA Phil players off the clock playing at the acoustically perfect American Legion Hall in Hollywood fortuitously found by Columbia producer John McClure for Walter’s Indian Summer recordings). This Haffner sounds perfect, suitably aristocratic to match the reason for its composition, and while not “historically informed” it is taut and percussive, defying the “Bach-maninoff” dig Ormandy sometimes receives. Although Webern’s Im Sommerwind is a warhorse commercially recorded by Ormandy and Philadelphia, I included it because our orchestra gave its world premiere in May of 1962, and this is its Philadelphia premiere. In fact, after the score was unearthed (literally) following Webern’s tragic death in 1945 at the hands of American forces in Austria and then lay fallow for two decades in the possession of Webern’s relatives, Im Sommerwind — which Webern had discarded as juvenilia after it was derided by Schoenberg — was given immediately to none other than Ormandy for a first performance by our orchestra. 

Ormandy’s correspondent was German-American musicologist and Webern biographer Hans Moldenhauer, who had heard that Webern’s relatives had in their possession a bust of the composer. He visited the family in 1961 and among their holdings found not only the bust but manuscripts, including that of Im Sommerwind. Moldenhauer arranged to have the score published and performed, the premiere taking place in May of 1962 with our orchestra under Ormandy’s baton, in conjunction with the Seattle World’s Fair and the simultaneous First International Webern Festival. It is a work that plays to this orchestra’s unmatched ability to infuse a score with nuanced color.

The second half of this same concert comprised the American premiere of the Shostakovich 4, uploaded separately in this channel.

Title: Mozart 39 Vn Cto 5 Francescatti Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1971 Live
Description: Philadelphia never commercially recorded the Mozart Symphony No. 39 or the Mozart Violin Concerto No. 5 under Ormandy (or under anyone else's baton, to my knowledge).  The second half of this concert included the Rozsa Theme and Variations and an intermission discussion with Francescatti (separately uploaded in this channel).  The sound in the symphony is quite good (those descending arpeggio runs in the first movement!), and for the concerto it's perfect, and Francescatti is closely miked and sounds great.

Title: Mozart 41 Liszt Cto 1 Cliburn Philadelphia Ormandy Aug 1968 Live
Description: The Mozart is terrific, and in good sound.  Ormandy and Philadelphia recorded the Jupiter commercially in May of 1968 for RCA, but I've never been able to hear it.  The Liszt is in even better sound, and Cliburn is in good form.  Three days after this concert, Ormandy and Cliburn recorded the Liszt 1 and the Grieg for RCA in a single day, probably their best work together commercially.

Title: Mozart Cto 25 LvB Cto 4 Cliburn Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1967 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra with soloist Van Cliburn in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 25 and Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4.  This pension fund concert also included Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2, separately uploaded in this channel.   The Mozart is fine, and the orchestral accompaniment is taut.  But in the Beethoven, Cliburn makes lots of mistakes, especially audible due to the dedicated piano microphone.  Serkin and Istomin, both of whom commercially recorded the 4th concerto with Ormandy in these decades, have nothing to fear from Cliburn.

Title: Ormandy conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra performing Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition
Ormandy/100 Member Congress of Strings: Barber Adagio (LIVE!)
Description:
The Music Makers: Angels of Grandeur and Epiphany

The American Federation of Musicians accomplished a wonderful thing in the 1960’s when they sponsored the Congress of Strings and moved mountains to establish a successful nearly ten year program aimed at promoting string playing in the United States and Canada and intensifying a nationwide interest in live music.

The photo shows Eugene Ormandy, noted conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, putting the Congress of Strings summer scholarship orchestra through its paces prior to conducting an enthusiastically received public concert Friday evening July 12, 1963 at Michigan State University (attached live recording). The 100-piece unit consists of youthful instrumentalists 15 to 22 years old. They are chosen in competitive auditions throughout the United States and Canada to attend an all-expense eight week summer session under the top first chair symphony teachers of the day, wholly sponsored by the American Federation of Musicians and some 700 affiliated locals. This post originated from the May 2014 sad news of the death of Paul Tobias, principal cellist in the photo. It reminded me of a very special, magical moment in my life and undoubtedly in the lives of many if not most of those one hundred string players that fateful day in the summer of 1963. In addition to Paul Tobias the other ‘cellists in the photo are Virginia Brown (now known as Jennifer Langham), Sally Guenther, and James Kreger. On the outside second stand first violins is Tania Rudensky from St. Catherines, Ontario, Canada. Years later she married Metropolitan Opera baritone Cornell MacNeil. Tania and I played quite a bit of chamber music together that summer, and before the end of our session she gave me a beautifully inscribed book, “The Art of String Quartet Playing,” which I treasure to this day.

The first rehearsal created an emotional groundswell. With great anticipation we all were looking forward to working with Eugene Ormandy, who for many years, along with Leopold Stokowski, preserved and cultivated the legendary Philadelphia Orchestra string sound. When Ormandy asked to begin with the Barber Adagio, something was about to happen in that large room at Williams Hall, Michigan State University. It would cast an indelible mark on the souls of 100 string players for the rest of our lives. As Maestro Ormandy held up his arms and began to conduct, what an incredible sound filled our space! It was an indescribable, unbelievably massive but hushed, wide sound, pregnant with pathos, enveloping everyone in its grandeur and majesty. It seemed as if we had been lifted out of our skins, transported by pure sound launching us up and out into the soul of the universe. It was as if we were not actually playing at all but riding some omnipotent divine wave. Looking back to the ecstasy of those few moments...which seemed timeless...I now realize we were experiencing what some would later describe as an epiphany.

- James Kreger, Cellist

Title: Petrassi Cto Orch 1 Stravinsky Firebird Philadelphia Rudolf Mar 1962 Live
Description: Max Rudolf, then music director of the Cincinnati, guest conducts Goffredo Petrassi's Concerto for Orchestra No. 1 (1934), the first of 8 increasingly and then decreasingly avant garde works, the last of which was completed in 1972.  An exciting and precise performance.  I left the Firebird Suite in.

Title: Piston Linc Ov Einem Phila Sym Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1962 Live
Description: A program featuring two Philadelphia commissions: Walter Piston’s Lincoln Center Festival Overture and Von Einem’s Philadelphia Symphony, here in its American premiere. Both were commissioned by EO and the PO. The Piston was commissioned to allow Philadelphia to strut its stuff in the service of celebrating the opening of Lincoln Center in NYC. It is truly congratulatory (and shares a bit in those congratulations) and the virtuosic playing it requires is exciting. Von Einem's Philadelphia Symphony, which seems to contain some allusions, celebrates the Academy of Music’s 104th anniversary, but was delayed in its performance when Ormandy got into a car accident which laid him up for a while. There are suggestions here and there that Ormandy’s car accident was just a pretext, and that the true reason for its delayed premiere was dissatisfaction with the work.

Title: Piston Linc Ov Lees Cto Str Quartet Strauss Till Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1970 Live
Description: The Lees is exciting and well played, and it is nice not to have to import a string quartet to take the lead role.  (Bill Smith wouldn't have made this mistake, but announcer Neill Curran misidentifies Joe De Pasquale as principal violin instead of viola.)  The work was commissioned by the Kansas City Philharmonic and premiered in 1965, and is probably the most frequently performed work by Benjamin Lees.  After hearing it, I think it should be performed more.  The Piston is exciting as heck and there is another, earlier performance on this channel to compare.  (The 1962 world premiere for the opening of Lincoln Center (the reason for the composition) was in mono, so I skipped it.)  Till is interesting.  It is played for character rather than sonority, and so is more like the 1952 commercial performance than the 1963, which I find values sonority over character.  Mason Jones really paces himself on those horn runs in this live performance, unlike in either commercial performance, and candidly I think Myron Bloom (Cleveland) bests Jones in the commercial recordings.  There is another commercial recording on RCA from 1974 that I've never been able to get my hands on.

Title: Poulenc Gloria Chopin Cto 1 Ohlsson Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1970 Live
Description: The first half of this concert was the lengthy Haydn Lord Nelson cantata.  Perhaps that's why both the Gloria and the Chopin (the Philadelphia debut for Ohlsson) are so significantly cut, which is disappointing because they are both so well played and sung.  The Poulenc is missing the Laudemus Te and the first Domine Deus, skipping directly from the Gloria to the Domine Fili Unigenite.  The accompaniment to the Poulenc is played very French, all clipped and nasal, EO and the players finding nice instrumental lines to highlight.  A listener points out below that the Chopin is cut in the first movement exposition.  It was commercially recorded 5 times by Philadelphia under EO, with Sandor, Brailowsky, Gilels, Cliburn, and Ax (the middle three in an 8-year period).  Ohlsson was just 22 at the time of this concert, fresh off his triumph in winning the Chopin competition in Warsaw, and he sounds just fantastic, silky smooth (those runs!) and powerful. Philadelphia recently got to hear Ohlsson in a perfect performance of the Beethoven Emperor, as a last minute substitution for Yefim Bronfman (who was nursing a hand injury) under Tugan Sokhiev's baton in April of 2025.

Title: Prokofiev 5 Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1975
Description: Prokofiev Symphony No. 5, Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy.  Recorded in September of 1975 for RCA.  This performance is not widely available.  I may be one of the only people in the world who prefers the 1957 performance on Columbia to this one, whose sonics are cavernous (like much of RCA's work for Philadelphia) and which lacks the elan and dash of the earlier performance (which Ormandy and Philadelphia reprised in Russia and Ukraine in the summer of 1958, available on the "Ormandy in Russia" series on Amazon Music Unlimited and Apple Music).  The earlier performance is available, stunningly remastered in the first Columbia Stereo box, and on all streaming platforms.

Title: Prokofiev Cto 3 Janis Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1963 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3. Eugene Ormandy conducts, with soloist Byron Janis. This was a pension fund concert, a concert that also included Janis playing Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 1 and the Schumann A minor concerto (separately posted on this channel).  Three concerti in one concert performance!  (Janis first performed this feat, in this same repertoire, during his 1962 tour of Russia.) The PO under Ormandy never commercially recorded the Prokofiev Cto 3; plans to do so were abandoned after Ormandy and Tedd Joselson had a falling out.  (A 1947 live performance with Kapell is available on streaming services.) This is an excellent performance, demonstrating Janis's virtuosic precision, Ormandy's skill as an accompanist, and the PO's poised athleticism in Prokofiev.  Janis was an RCA and Mercury artist, and so made no commercial recordings with Philadelphia, even after Philadelphia jumped back from Columbia to RCA in late 1968, but did perform live in subscription concerts relatively frequently (in 1954, 1957, 1960, 1963, 1967, and 1971).  Program notes are spoken by William Smith, the orchestra‘s longtime assistant conductor. Be sure to compare this performance to the later subscription concert performance.

Title: Prokofiev Kije Stravinsky Sym 3 Mvts Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1962 Live
Description: Prokofiev’s Lieutenant Kije Suite is being rehearsed in advance of the commercial recording in December. For once, I think the sonics in the commercial issue surpass those of Messrs. Borkow and Sacks. The real attraction here is the Stravinsky Symphony in Three Movements, a thrilling neoclassical work composed for the NYPO in the mid-1940s. A real showpiece that will put even a virtuoso orchestra like this one to the test, even if the work is really just a cobbled-together array of abandoned compositional pieces.

Title: Prokofiev Romeo Stravinsky Fairy's Kiss Divertimento Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1965 Live
Prokofiev Scythian Cto 3 Janis Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1963 Live
Description: This concert was devoted to Prokofiev, in recognition of the 10th anniversary of his death. The Scythian Suite was commercially recorded by Philadelphia and Ormandy only in mono (1947), remastered as well as can be expected in the 2021 Ormandy box set. It is good to be able to hear Prokofiev’s gift for storytelling in modern stereo sound. Ormandy’s disciplined maintenance of proportion, careful dynamics, and refusal to allow excessive intensity to distort the music pay dividends here, enhancing rather than sacrificing drama. It cannot be easy on the brass to keep a lid on it, but they nail it. Although I previously uploaded Janis’s earlier Prokofiev Cto 3, the last work in his 3-concerto marathon for that pension fund concert, I did not delete this later singleton performance, which permits comparison. Surprisingly, despite markedly different conditions and slightly different sound pictures (this later performance mikes Janis more closely and may on the whole be finer sound-wise), I think Janis sounds remarkably consistent between performances.

Title: Rach Preludes 1-3 Cto 2 Davis Philadelphia Ormandy Apr 1963 Live
Description: The Preludes, arranged by former Philadelphia Orchestra clarinetist Lucien Cailliet are not just beautifully arranged (I would put him up against Ravel any day, including in Pictures at an Exhibition, and he is preferable to Stokowski and Ormandy as an arranger to my ear, too) and sumptuously played as you would expect. Ivan Davis, who left us in 2018, was just 31 at the time of this performance and would go on to record this concerto (and many others) for Columbia with Kostelanetz. There’s a great picture of him from around this time in Adrian Siegel’s Concerto for Camera. He appeared on TV with Ormandy and Philadelphia, and would go on to record Liszt’s Hungarian Fantasy on Columbia, available on the First Chair Encores Vol. 2, in the second stereo Ormandy Box.

Title: Rachmaninoff 2 Philadelphia Ormandy April 1961 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Rachmaninoff's Symphony No. 2, live in a subscription concert for the 1960-61 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  This performance does not meet the prerequisites for inclusion in this channel because it's easy to get the 1959 Columbia stereo version (cut) and the 1973 RCA stereo version (uncut), but this performance is white hot and near perfect; Ormandy sets a brisk tempo and pushes the orchestra hard, and they meet his every demand with refined ferocity and lush intensity. This was the closing work of this April 8, 1961 concert; the opening work was Vocalese and then Istomin playing the second piano concerto in stereo, the latter unavailable elsewhere. They are included elsewhere on this channel.

Title: Rachmaninoff Cto 1 Schumann Cto Janis Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1963 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 1 and Schumann's Piano Concerto, live in a pension fund concert. Eugene Ormandy conducts, with soloist Byron Janis. This concert also included Janis playing Prokofiev's Piano Concerto No. 3 (separately posted on this channel). Three concerti in one concert performance!  (Janis first performed this feat, in this same repertoire, during his 1962 tour of Russia.) Janis was an RCA and Mercury artist, and so made no commercial recordings with Philadelphia, even after Philadelphia jumped back to RCA from Columbia in late 1968, but did perform live in subscription concerts relatively frequently (in 1954, 1957, 1960, 1963, 1967, and 1971).  The opening work is the Purcell trumpet voluntary (which wasn’t by Purcell and isn’t a voluntary) played very well by Gil Johnson, so I left it in.  Program notes are spoken by William Smith, the orchestra’s longtime assistant conductor.  The real attraction here is the Prokofiev, not these other warhorses (commercially recorded by PO/Ormandy with Entremont and Serkin (3x!) respectively), but hearing Janis with Philadelphia under Ormandy, instead of with Chicago under Reiner (or Minneapolis or Moscow under Skrowaczewski or Kondrashin), is a real treat.

Title: Rachmaninoff Cto 2 Istomin Philadelphia Ormandy Apr 1961 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Rachmaninoff's Vocalese and then Piano Concerto No. 2 with soloist Eugene Istomin, live in a subscription concert for the 1960-61 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  In April of 1956, Istomin recorded with Ormandy and Philly what some consider to be the definitive performance of this concerto.  But it was in mono, leaving many to pine for a stereo version.  Pine no more:  this is that version.  Istomin, a consummate artistic professional, strikes an ideal balance between articulation and passion, and the orchestral accompaniment is everything you would expect. Since this was an all-Rachmaninoff concert that included the Second symphony, I will include the Vocalese in this video and the symphony in another video, even though they don’t meet the main prerequisite for inclusion that I set for this channel:  difficult/impossible to obtain in a commercial recording.  This piano concerto, by contrast, is exactly what I created this channel for.

Title: Rachmaninoff Cto 3 Cliburn Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1961 Live
Description: This is an excellent stereo performance of the Third concerto, that renders the later mono version celebrating the opening of Lincoln Center (available elsewhere on this channel) not really comparable due to the latter's limited sound picture.  Here, despite Bill Smith's closing comments about how this concerto is really a tone poem with the piano no more prominent than the orchestra, Cliburn's piano is miked far more prominently than the orchestra, taking up practically the entire right channel, allowing us to scrutinize his near-perfect performance, somewhat at the expense of the recessed orchestral accompaniment.

Title: Rachmaninoff Cto 3 Cliburn Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1962 Live (mono)
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast (in mono) of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3 live in a gala concert commemorating the opening of Lincoln Center in 1962.  Eugene Ormandy conducts, with soloist Van Cliburn.  The recording setup was mono, not stereo, but I am posting this because Cliburn, an RCA artist, was famous for his Rachmaninoff, and after Philadelphia jumped back to RCA in late 1968 the only Rachmaninoff he recorded with Philadelphia was the Paganini Rhapsody with Ormandy.  (RCA recorded Ashkenazy in the Third concerto with Philadelphia and Ormandy in 1975.) Cliburn’s performance is nearly mistake free, and he is in top form, all power and precision married with graceful fluidity. Program notes are spoken by William Smith, the orchestra‘s longtime assistant conductor. ￼

Title: Rachmaninoff: Rhap'y...Paganini (Nissman; Phil. Orch./Ormandy)
Description:
Pianist Barbara Nissman with the Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy, performing 'Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini', Op. 43, by Sergei Rachmaninoff. The performance, on November 6, 1972, was Barbara Nissman's professional American debut. 

The second film in Barbara Nissman's Master Class Series, 'Alberto Ginastera, A Man of Latin America', has been released in a set of two DVDs. The first DVD presents an in-depth portrait of Alberto Ginastera and includes performance excerpts and interviews with the composer himself, his daughter and his widow. You will also hear conductor Leonard Slatkin discussing Ginastera's last orchestral work, Keith Emerson of ELP remembering meeting Ginastera, and an encounter with Chick Corea who was a big fan of his music. The second DVD is a master class with Nissman at the piano, discussing and performing his three piano sonatas (his Third Sonata was dedicated to her) and his early Danzas Argentinas. Here's a preview:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zSzRMIoJacQ
The film can be purchased at Nissman's website:
https://threeorangesrecordings.com/alberto-ginastera-a-man-of-latin-america
It is also available at Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/ALBERTO-GINASTERA-America-Barbara-Nissman/dp/B0BC6QBQSW/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pb_opt?ie=UTF8
Barbara Nissman's website is accessible at http://www.barbaranissman.com/ and her Wikipedia page at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Nissman

Title: Rivier 5 Roussel Bacchus Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1967 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Jean Rivier’s Symphony No. 5 and Roussel’s Bacchus and Ariane. The Rivier, composed in 1950 (Bill Smith says 1951 in his spoken commentary), is a pleasant surprise, an exciting neoclassical work. Philadelphia has never commercially recorded any Rivier, but his symphonies were programmed in the 1950s and 60s (3 and 5 (twice) by EO and 6 by Pretre guest conducting). I left in the Roussel, which was commercially recorded in 1960 and remastered beautifully and very effectively in the first Ormandy stereo box. Its bacchanalian climax shows off Philly’s (and Gil Johnson’s) virtuosity thrillingly, moreso in the studio but here, too.

Title: Rochberg Zodiac LvB Cto 5 Barenboim Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1967 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Rochberg’s Zodiac and Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 5 (“Emperor”) with Daniel Barenboim as soloist. This was Barenboim’s debut with Philly; over the prior two months he had commercially recorded all of the Beethoven piano concerti with Klemperer and the Philharmonia on EMI. I find Barenboim’s pianism here even more leaden and labored than in that traversal; perhaps this is just an illusion and Klemp’s own leaden and labored accompaniment somewhat camouflaged this quality in Barenboim’s playing. Philadelphia’s accompaniment here is taut and lithe rather than grazioso, once again belying the trope that Philly’s execution was mindlessly and uniformly legato. The Rochberg is well played but in Rochberg’s view poorly conducted — please read his transcribed interview excerpts posted elsewhere on this channel to hear his unvarnished views of EO. The comments below likewise feature some unvarnished views of Rochberg’s Zodiac.

Title: Rodrigo Harp Cto Costello Strauss Rosenkavalier Philadelphia Ormandy Apr 1967 Live
Description: Marilyn Costello sounds great in the Rodrigo.  Her predecessors Edna Phillips and Marjorie Tyre are the harpists depicted in the banner artwork for this channel (downstage, as Stokowski and Ormandy liked it and, for various and wholly justified reasons, Ms. Phillips, Ms. Tyre and Ms. Costello hated it, causing Ormandy at some point to relent).  I left the Rosenkavalier suite in, although it is the very definition of an Ormandy/PO warhorse, played to death on demand as Brusilow amusingly recounts in Shoot the Conductor.

Title: Roger Sessions: Symphony No 5 [Ormandy-Philadelphia Orch] archival sound
Description: Roger Sessions: Symphony No 5 [Eugene Ormandy-Philadelphia Orchestra]. recorded for radio broadcast. archival sound quality.

Title: Roussel 4 Chabrier Espana Ravel Espagnole Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1963 Live
Description: The Roussel 4, composed in 1934, was never commercially recorded by Philadelphia (Bacchus and Ariane was the only Roussel to make it into the studio under Ormandy).  I left the Chabrier in, which immediately following this concert would be recorded in stereo by Columbia in Town Hall a/k/a the Scottish Rite Cathedral, the second of three commercial recordings by Philadelphia under Ormandy (brisk in 1954, moderately paced in 1963 [exactly like this live performance], and way too slow in 1972).  I also left in the Ravel, which after this concert went with the Chabrier straight into the recording studio as the third of three commercial releases by Philadelphia and Ormandy, and the first in stereo.

Title: Rozsa Notturno LvB 7 Philadelphia Ormandy Apr 1964 Live
Description: Ormandy conducts the world premiere of Miklos Rozsa's Hungarian Nocturne (Notturno Ungherese), with Rozsa present.  What a beautiful composition, beautifully played.  Philadelphia never commercially recorded any of Rozsa's works, but his fellow Hungarian Ormandy programmed him in concert relatively often (the original version of the Theme, Variations and Finale in April of 1948, the Vintner's Daughter in March of 1956, the Violin Concerto in March of 1958 under Bill Smith's baton with concertmaster Jake Krachmalnick as soloist, the Concerto for String Orchestra in March of 1958, the Piano Concerto in September of 1968 under Rozsa's own baton, and a revised version of the Theme, Variations and Finale in January 1971, separately uploaded in this channel).  I left the Beethoven Symphony No. 7 in.

Title: Rozsa Theme Var Paganini Caprices Francescatti Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1971 Live
Description: This is the second half of the concert that opened with the Mozart 39 and Francescatti playing the Mozart violin concerto No. 5, separately uploaded in this channel. It begins with the intermission interview of Francescatti, who is gregarious and knowledgeable. The Rozsa Op. 13, his first major compositional success, heard here in its 1966 version, is exciting and played to a fare-thee-well. Harold Sacks, who assisted Albert Borkow, Jr. in these fantastic airchecks and who was a charter member of the Rozsa Society, comments below on the work’s significance to the career of Bernstein. Then Francescatti returns for two Paganini caprices, IX and XXIV, both of whose accompaniment he arranged for orchestra. The latter will be familiar as the one arranged for piano and orchestra by Rachmaninoff. I bet the smell of burning rosin was detectable in the first several rows of seats.

Title: Saint Saens Vn Cto 3 Francescatti Debussy Mer Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1964 Live
Description: After Joe Santarlasci, manager of the orchestra, is interviewed by Bill Smith and offers amusing anecdotes about touring mishaps, frequent live and in-studio soloist with the Philadelphia, Zino Francescatti, then 61 years of age, plays the Saint-Saens Violin Concerto No. 3 with silken tone and perfect intonation, seeming effortlessly.  Philadelphia never commercially recorded any of the three Saint-Saens violin concerti under Ormandy.  I left warhorse La Mer in, which was "only" commercially recorded twice by Ormandy and Philadelphia (once in 1959 on Columbia, remastered in the first Ormandy Stereo box and once in 1972 on RCA, available in the 20th Century collection).  It was programmed 14 times between 1959 and 1980, according to the folks who collect this data at the Concert Annals blog.  Though with the diversity of repertoire we have seen so far, it's hard to complain about repetition of crowd favorites.

Title: Schuman 6 Buxtehude Passacaglia arr. Cailliet Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1963 Live
Description: This concert included the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 with Cliburn, uploaded separately on this channel.  This program to my mind presents a good example of Ormandy programming in the 1960s:  the bitter pill of a serious contemporary work (with the composer present), sugared for the audience on either end by a gooey arrangement of an organ passacaglia and a popular 19th century concerto with an acclaimed virtuoso soloist that would allow the audience to leave humming the last work it heard.  Perhaps with growing familiarity the audience would want it to hear the modern work again, allowing it to creep into the basic repertoire. Philadelphia commercially released the Schuman 6 under Ormandy in 1953, available remastered in the first Ormandy Columbia box (the mono one).
