Title: Schumann 2 Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1962 Live
Description: This is another Schumann 2.  The comparison to the 1964 live Schumann 2, separately uploaded in this channel, is interesting.  The sound here in 1962 is closer up and I think better.  However, the 1964 performance is more intense, fiery and driven, with quicker tempi.  This one is a bit more polite and reserved.  Both performances are great, though, and the lyricism that EO draws out of the third movement (in both performances) is to my ear a revelation.

Title: Schumann 2 Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1964 Live
Description: I absolutely love the extroverted RCA stereo set from 1977-78 with that guest conductor I shall not name, and the Second might be the crown jewel of that set.  The way Norman Carol leads the first violins in mvt. ii is just sublime.  But extroversion is one thing; interesting balances, phrasing, and color are another.  By that measure, this is a wonderful performance, far more interesting in my opinion than EO's 1937 mono performance on RCA.  Why he never returned to the studio to record the 4 Schumann symphonies is a mystery to me.  (I realize I keep forgetting to mention Sawallisch's set, which features many of our current players, but we had already said goodbye to Ondine (or vice versa), and our in-house sound was seriously lacking, disserving Mr. Liuzzi's timpani in particular.)

Title: Schumann 3 Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1961 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Schumann Symphony No. 3 ("Rhenish") live in a subscription concert for the 1960-61 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  William Smith provides program-note commentary (in mono sound) but the performance is captured in stereo.  With the exception of the 1937 recording of the Second (Philadelphia) and the 1934 recording of the Fourth (Minneapolis), there are no extant commercial recordings of Ormandy conducting any Schumann symphonies, although he programmed them often.  There is a fabulous set of the four recorded by Philadelphia in 1977-78 for RCA under the baton of a guest conductor and recorded in Philadelphia's Scottish Rite Cathedral a/k/a Town Hall. (There is also a traversal by Sawallisch at Marian Anderson Hall, but the in-house sound isn't very good, making Don Liuzzi’s timpani sound uncharacteristically tubby.)  This 1961 performance is as percussive as it is cantabile, and Ormandy’s balances (and “judicious” rescoring, Bill Smith discloses) reveal Schumann’s gorgeous harmonies. Mason Jones's heroic horn call in the recapitulation of i is just slightly less extroverted here than in the 1977 commercial recording for RCA (I assume that's Jones in 1977 and not Nolan Miller). The low brass are both muscular and refined in iv.  It is a mystery why Ormandy did not return to the studio for a Schumann traversal and instead ceded the repertoire to a guest conductor.

Title: Shostakovich 15 Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1972 Live
Shostakovich 4 USA Premiere Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1963 Live
Description: Besides being an important occasion in international musical history, this performance presents an interesting comparison to the studio performance captured a day or so after this live concert. This performance is grittier and gutsier. And it was the last work in a program that did not entirely spare the brass — the Haffner and Im Sommerwind preceded it (also available separately on this channel since EO/Philly never commercially recorded the Haffner).  Yet the brass’s chops are strutting their stuff impressively.

Title: Shostakovich Vn Cto 1 Menuhin Stravinsky Fireworks Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1961 Live
Description: The Stravinsky is an exciting, youthful work. The Shostakovich is a masterpiece, and this performance marked its debut in Philadelphia. There are no commercial recordings of Ormandy and Philadelphia in either of Shostakovich’s violin concerti, and this appears to be not just the first but the only recording of Ormandy conducting the First live. (There is a recording of him conducting Oistrakh in the Second with the LSO in November of 1967 elsewhere on YouTube.) Philadelphia has since accompanied many soloists in the First, including Maazel in 1968 (with Oistrakh), Yannick in 2015, and our former conductor-in-residence Macelaru in 2019. Menuhin sounds just perfect in this repertoire.

Title: Sibelius 5 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1960 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of Philadelphia Orchestra playing Sibelius Symphony No. 5 live in a subscription concert for the 1960-61 season.  Eugene Ormandy conducts.  I included this because I suspected that this live stereo performance from 1960 would bear more of the characteristics of the 1954 mono commercial recording on Columbia than of the 1975 stereo commercial recording on RCA.  I think my suspicions are borne out.  And let me exercise my privilege as channel operator to add one gratuitous and perhaps unkind comment:  Ormandy is miles ahead of recent Finnish guest conductors Stasevska and even Salonen in achieving suitable balances among the sections of the PO in the loud tutti passages of this work. Considering the clogged sound Stasevska created (Salonen, one of her teachers, created a far better sound), I thought that maybe Ormandy simply had the benefit of a recording studio, but this live performance suggests the real reason: his skill as a conductor. I also have a live performance from Oct of 1963 that sounds less like the 1954 and more like the 1975, but will post it only if people ask.

Title: Sibelius En Saga Tartini Vc Cto Munroe Philadelphia Smith Jan 1963 Live
Description: Assistant conductor William Smith leads the Philadelphia Orchestra in Sibelius’s short tone poem En Saga, just two weeks before the orchestra and Ormandy would commercially record the work the second time (the first in stereo) for Columbia. Interesting to note that Smith’s timing (19 mins) is two minutes longer than Ormandy’s Columbia stereo version, three minutes longer than Ormandy’s earlier Columbia mono version (1955), and one minute longer than Ormandy’s later RCA stereo version (1975). En Saga sounds just as good live as in the recording studio.  The Tartini Cello Concerto is a vehicle to show off the tone of Lorne Munroe, principal cello who, in a couple of years, would be poached by Bernstein and head to New York.  The second half of this concert will also feature Munroe in Kabalevsky's Cello Concerto No. 1, separately uploaded in this channel.

Title: Spohr Cto for Str Qtet Sessions 5 Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1964 Live
Description: It is always nice to hear first chairs of the orchestra in soloist (or in this case, quartet) roles, rather than ringers.  The Sessions 5 is a world premiere, commissioned by Ormandy in 1960 and finished when Sessions was 68 years of age.  It was never commercially recorded by Ormandy/Philadelphia. Do not pay any mind to the Wikipedia entry declaring that this performance is only of the first movement and the symphony was not complete until December of 1964.  As Bill Smith explains, all three movements are here, played without pause.

Title: Strauss Enoch Arden arr  Cailliet Raines Philadelphia Ormandy March 1961 Live
Strauss Festliches Danae Daphne Guden Domestica Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1964 Live
Description: This concert commemorated Richard Strauss's 100th birthday.  A challenging breakpoint between halves of this concert prevented me from presenting the Domestica separately, so this is the whole concert in one shot.  It is nice to have Ormandy conducting a stereo version of the Domestica, and in such vivid color. For comparison, there is an excellent version on YouTube from 1993 with Sawallisch conducting at Suntory Hall, back when Jeffrey Khaner still had hair. There are no commercial versions by the PO other than the 1938 mono on Victor. I don't know how Bill Smith both announced the program and played organ in the Praludium, but according to the archival material that's what he did.  (See the comment below in which a professional sound engineer explains those mechanics.) The Praludium is a bonkers fanfare, way over the top, and should be heard more, even if some consider it a trashy monstrosity (which can be a virtue!). Hilde Guden’s voice is just lovely, and powerful.

Title: Strauss Metamorphosen Jongen Organ Sym Philadelphia Smith Dec 1964 Live
Description: It is nice to hear Bill Smith, a devoted assistant conductor if ever there was one, leading these performances.  The Jongen is thrilling (the audience justifiably goes wild at the end), and Virgil Fox should be a familiar name to those who own the Philly Saint-Saens Organ Symphony on RCA.  Rossen Milanov, another fine associate conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, more recently led the Jongen with well known Philadelphia organ soloist Peter Richard Conte playing the famous Wanamaker Organ in Philadelphia in 2008, a good performance (albeit with lots of hall reverberation and long decay --- Wanamaker's is a giant cavern, after all, and the organ pipes are spread out) available on all streaming services.  Ormandy did not program or commercially record the Metamorphosen until 1978, on an RCA issue I have never been able to get my hands on.

Title: Szymon Goldberg - Brahms Violin Concerto - Eugene Ormandy, Philadelphia Orchestra 1957 Live
Tchaik Cto 1 Magaloff Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1961 Live
Description: The Balakirev Islamey arranged by Casella is not here, but is instead in the upload containing the Kabalevsky Second Symphony (from the same concert).  Apologies for my confusion. This is just Magaloff playing the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 1, which Ormandy and Philadelphia commercially recorded 3x (with Levant in mono and Istomin in stereo for Columbia, and with Joselson for RCA).  Magaloff, a serious pedagogue of other virtuosi who was in the midst of a worldwide tour, makes lots of mistakes in trying to deliver the electricity this work calls for, a work he would go on to record commercially twice (once with the Hague and once with the NDR).  The orchestra delivers the high voltage brilliantly.

Title: Tchaik Romeo Kabalevsky 2 Balakirev Islamey Philadelphia Ormandy Feb 1961 Live
Description: The last work in this upload is the Balakirev Islamey arranged by Alfredo Casella. It follows the Kabalevsky Symphony No. 2. Eugene Ormandy conducts first the Tchaikovsky Romeo and Juliet Fantasy-Overture, with his trademark cymbal crash additions. Reviewers of the EO/Philly commercial recordings of this work (1953, 1964, 1973) condemn those added crashes as vulgarities, but I think playing this dignified can accommodate a little trashiness without compromising its high level of musicality, to say nothing of the intense drama the orchestra whips up. The Kabalevsky is an appealing Soviet realist work, affording plenty of opportunities to show off our orchestra’s collective virtuosity. But it’s the Balakirev/Casella that really allows Philly to strut its stuff with this exciting showpiece that Ormandy builds to a bonkers ending climax.  The orchestra would commercially record Islamey a week later (alongside Strauss's Don Quixote and part of the Mozart Horn Concerto No. 4).  I much prefer the sonics that Messrs. Borkow and Sacks achieve here to those that Columbia producer John McClure would achieve a week later in Town Hall a/k/a Scottish Rite Cathedral.

Title: Tchaik Romeo Vn Cto Milstein Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1964 Live
Description: From this all-Tchaikovsky concert, here is a Romeo and Juliet that begins rather tepidly to my ear but which intensifies at the first climax and stays intense until its conclusion. Excluding early Stokowski from 1928 on Victor, there are five commercial versions of this work, from 1953 (in the first Ormandy mono box), 1964 (in the second Columbia stereo box), 1973 (in the Ormandy Tchaikovsky box issued by Sony of mostly RCA recordings with EO against a purple background), 1988 (Muti on EMI), and 2008 (Eschenbach on Ondine). Nathan Milstein was not quite 60 at the time of this excellent performance of the violin concerto, marred only by some occasional unsteadiness in the horns. He has just two commercial recordings with Philadelphia, in 1944/1945 (the Lalo Symphonie Espagnole, which I believe is the earliest entry in the Ormandy mono box) and a 1951 Brahms concerto for Vn and Vc with Piatagorsky on RCA, with Reiner conducting the pseudonymous Robin Hood Dell orchestra (to circumvent Columbia’s contractual restrictions), but was a relatively frequent live soloist from the mid-1950s to mid-1960s, and then twice between 1979 and 1980, playing standard concerto fare: Beethoven, Brahms, Dvorak, and Bruch.

Title: Thorne Elegy Chopin Cto 1 Gilels Philadelphia Ormandy Nov 1964 Live
Description: The Thorne Elegy is its American Premiere.  The Chopin Piano Concerto No. 1, here full of fingering mistakes by Gilels and in sound that is rather distant most of the time, would 5 weeks later be commercially recorded by Columbia at the Broadwood Hotel's Crystal Ballroom on New Year's Eve, even though Ormandy and Brailowsky's Chopin 1 had been recorded and released on Columbia just three years prior.  Gilels was on a recording and concert tear in America and Russia in 1964, simultaneously recording for RCA (the Living Stereo Liszt/Schubert Sonatas) and Columbia and concertizing as far west as the Seattle Opera House (a recital privately recorded and then licensed and issued by DG).

Title: Wagner Parsifal Francaix L'Horloge De Lancie Ravel Alborada Philadelphia Ormandy April 1961 Live
Description: Before the world premiere of Francaix's seven-section oboe work, Eugene Ormandy conducts the Act I Prelude (Vorspiel) to Wagner's Parsifal, a staple of Philadelphia's repertoire under Stokowski and Ormandy, commercially recorded several times on Victor, Columbia, and RCA.  Some technical glitches in the transfer of this recording to CD are the only issues with this beautiful performance that shows our brass off to its best advantage.  And just listen to that gorgeous phrasing throughout the work.  I prefer this performance to the 1970 RCA one (issued with the sonically disastrous Mahler Resurrection, both works typically being performed over the Easter season).  The most notable gem here is the world premiere of L'horloge de flore (The Flower Clock or Flora's Clock) by Jean Françaix.  The work was commissioned by (and is dedicated to) John De Lancie, principal oboe. It was completed in 1959, was premiered by De Lancie in this performance.  It definitely shows off De Lancie's virtuosity and beautiful tone; whether it's an enduring work is debatable.  Ravel's Alborada del Gracioso, an exciting showpiece played with precision and gusto, had been commercially recorded by Ormandy in 1958 on Columbia (and would be re-recorded by Muti in 1982 on EMI). You can also find on this channel a version conducted by Stokowski in a December 1962 pension fund concert.

Title: Webern Passacaglia Sibelius 4 Philadelphia Stokowski Mar 1962 Live
Description: Webern's Passacaglia, written when he was 25, is gorgeous.  It was written after the posthumously discovered Im Sommerwind (which would not be given its world premiere until two months after this performance), but still is listed as his Op. 1.  The Sibelius Symphony No. 4 performance I find idiosyncratic.  I am used to its bleakness being delivered with playing characterized by intense concentration and tightly controlled attacks, decays, and dynamics.  Stokowski does not exert that control and as a consequence I find this performance episodic and lacking in tension and cohesiveness.  There are great moments, to be sure.

Title: Zador 5 Contrasts Haydn Vc Cto 2 Hilger Philadelphia Ormandy Jan 1965 Live
Zador Festival Ov Bartok Vn Cto 2 Menuhin Philadelphia Ormandy Dec 1967 Live
Zador Rhapsodie Dvorak 9 Philadelphia Ormandy April 1963 Live
Description: The Zador is excellent. The stereo commercial release of the Dvorak 9 on Columbia was with the LSO, recorded in November of 1966.  There's a stereo RCA performance with Philly that I haven't heard.  Although there is some distortion at fff dynamics, this performance’s balances are quintessential Ormandy. In ii, Louis Roseblatt’s cor anglais (I assume that’s him) is poignant and De Lancie and Panitz’s contributions make this a gem of a movement that seduces and tickles the ear.

Title: Schumann Pf Cto Istomin Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1974 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Schumann’s Piano Concerto with Eugene Istomin as soloist. The upload begins with an interview with Istomin (conducted by George Diehl, who seems incapable of vibing with any interviewee) that is remarkable for Istomin’s detailed expressions of adulation for the Philadelphia Orchestra, with whom he has soloed for 31 years. This is the first time Istomin and Philly have collaborated in the Schumann. The performance can be compared both to his 1959 commercial performance with Walter (Columbia Symphony Orchestra, not sure if it was recorded in NY or LA, but the producer was Columbia’s John McClure) and to his teacher Rudolf Serkin’s commercial performances (3x) with Philadelphia under Ormandy. Serkin’s crystal clear and plainspoken articulation has always appealed to me because it contrasts so pleasantly with the plush accompaniment Philly supplies. Well, Istomin has Serkin’s articulation but also an impetuous streak, both with Walter but moreso with Ormandy here, and with a far better ensemble, making for a heart-on-sleeve performance with swooping gestures coming from both the keyboard and the ensemble. Decadently romantic but never garish.

Title: Bruckner 7 Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1974 Live
Description:
Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Bruckner’s Symphony No. 7, nearly 6 years after commercially recording it for RCA. This performance is included on this channel because it is very different from the commercial one (also included on this channel in view of its relative unavailability), both in the sound picture and in pacing. This live performance is more expansive than the brisk RCA. Timings help tell the story:

       1968 RCA:     This one:   
I:       17:29              19:00
II:      18:46              19:32
III:       9:12                9:37
IV:     10:11               10:40

This live performance is also better recorded than the commercial version and so better captures the careful balances being imposed by (and on) the players. No one is drowned out by anyone else, even in the tutti fortissimo passages. You hear every instrumental line; you will hear bits of the score you didn’t know were there (particularly evident in the Scherzo). Crescendos are kept in proportion, building with disciplined steadiness to dignified climaxes. Attacks and decays, especially in the horns and brass, maintain perfect ensemble. And the blend in the horns and low brass is remarkable. Such control! Are those two woodwind overblows in the B section of the Scherzo on purpose? And the strings in the Adagio (and the B section of the Scherzo) are just gorgeous. This is a superlative performance in every way; I cannot say enough about it.

Title: Brahms Haydn Var Harris 3 Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1974 Live
Kirchner Music Orch Schumann 1 Philadelphia Ormandy May 1974 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Kirchner’s Music for Orchestra and then Schumann’s Symphony No. 1 (“Spring”).  Kirchner composed Music for Orchestra on a commission from the New York Philharmonic to celebrate its 125th anniversary in 1969. Critic Anthony Tommasini of The New York Times described Music for Orchestra as “a transfixing, often subdued piece that spotlights different groups of instruments, alternating between pensive lyricism and cascades of activity.” The Schumann is just brilliant. The orchestra plays it like it’s the finest piece of music ever, with interesting balances and gorgeous, characterful phrasing that is both percussive and cantabile.

Title: LvB Prometheus Mozart Vn Cto 3 Perlman Philadelphia Ormandy Mar 1974 Live
Bruckner 9 Te Deum Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1974 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Bruckner's Symphony No. 9 with the Te Deum as the 4th movement (something YNS did recently and which Bruckner himself apparently suggested be done).  The tempi here are brisk.  Very brisk.  Like Salonen’s recent guest conducting gig here in Bruckner and Mozart, the tempi here suggest that EO maybe had a plane to catch.  The first half of this concert was a 30-minute-long Bach Cantata, so perhaps EO was trying to shorten this long concert.

Title: Ives Harvest Chorales Psalm 150 Holidays Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1974 Live
Liszt Salutarem Undam Cochereau Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1974 Live
LvB 7 Maw Scenes Philadelphia Ormandy Sept 1974 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 and in the western hemisphere premiere of Nicholas Maw's Scenes and Arias with soloists Benita Valente, Janice Harsanyi (apologies for the typo in the thumbnail, thanks to Colin Anderson for pointing that out), and Betty Allen.  Maw, a Brit, is present for this premiere.  Valente, Harsanyi and Allen are all familiar vocalists over these decades, and it is nice to hear Valente, who recently passed (typing this in early November of 2025).  The Maw, commissioned by the BBC and premiered at one of the BBC Proms, is not familiar but sounds like it's played very, very well, and all three vocalists are in terrific form.  When it received its world premiere in 1962, the work was hailed as a masterpiece, and Maw's refusal to abandon tonality was celebrated.  I left in the Beethoven, and I am glad I did.  As commenters observe, it's a far less dignified performance than the April 1964 commercial performance on Columbia, more percussive and unbuttoned.  EO lets the timpanist (Carlyss?  Bookspan?) turn up the volume substantially.

Title: Tchaik 3 Philadelphia Ormandy Oct 1974 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 3 (the "Polish").  This upload begins with an intermission interview with Austrian pianist Walter Klien, who in the first half of this concert (which celebrated the 100th birthday of Arnold Schoenberg) played Schoenberg's Concerto for Piano and Orchestra, separately uploaded in this channel.  This performance of the Tchaikovsky is just beautiful and energetic, and interestingly follows the commercial recording session for RCA rather than vice versa.  (EO often used the live concerts as a rehearsal vehicle prior to recording, but not here.)  As other commenters observe, its energy compares favorably to the more polite commercial recording.  What a finale!
